question: A.01 [1.0 point] The THERMAL UTILIZATION FACTOR is defined as a ratio of:

answers.answer: a. the number of fast neutrons produced by fission in a generation to the number of total neutrons produced by fission in the previous generation.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: b. the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel to the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel and core materials.
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: c. the number of fast neutrons produced by U-238 to the number of thermal neutrons absorbed in fuel.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.1

answers.answer: d. the number of fast neutrons that start to slow down to the number of fast neutrons from all fissions.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.3.1

question: A.02 [1.0 point] The neutron count rate is 1000 cps. An experimenter inserts an experiment into the core and the count rate decreases to 725 cps. Given the initial Keff of the reactor was 0.91, what is the worth of the experiment?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 – keff2) / (1 - keff1) 1000 / 725 = (1- keff2) / (1 – 0.92) Therefore: keff2 = 0.876 ∆ρ = (keff2 - keff1) / (keff2 * keff1) ∆ρ = (0.876 – 0.91) / (0.876 * 0.91) ∆ρ = - 0.0427

Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 – keff2) / (1 - keff1) 1000 / 725 = (1- keff2) / (1 – 0.92) Therefore: keff2 = 0.876 ∆ρ = (keff2 - keff1) / (keff2 * keff1) ∆ρ = (0.876 – 0.91) / (0.876 * 0.91) ∆ρ = - 0.0427

Incorrect. REFERENCE: CR1 / CR2 = (1 – keff2) / (1 - keff1) 1000 / 725 = (1- keff2) / (1 – 0.92) Therefore: keff2 = 0.876 ∆ρ = (keff2 - keff1) / (keff2 * keff1) ∆ρ = (0.876 – 0.91) / (0.876 * 0.91) ∆ρ = - 0.0427

question: A.04 [1.0 point] Which ONE of the following describes Integral Rod Worth?

answers.answer: a. The remaining reactivity worth of a rod up to the point of withdrawal
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: b. The plot of the slope of the change in reactivity over the change in rod position (Δρ/Δx)
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: c. The reactivity change per unit movement of a rod.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

answers.answer: d. The total reactivity worth of the rod at a particular degree of withdrawal
answers.feedback: Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.4, page 3-32

question: A.06 [1.0 point] Given a reactor period of 38 seconds, approximately how long will it take power to quadruple?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0et/T 4 = 1 · et/38 t = 38 · ln(4) t = 52.7 sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0et/T 4 = 1 · et/38 t = 38 · ln(4) t = 52.7 sec
Correct. REFERENCE: P = P0et/T 4 = 1 · et/38 t = 38 · ln(4) t = 52.7 sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0et/T 4 = 1 · et/38 t = 38 · ln(4) t = 52.7 sec

question: A.07 [1.0 point] What is the fraction of thermal neutrons absorbed in U-235 by fission? Given Isotope 92U²³⁵, σᵳ = 577 barns, σc = 106 barns. Note: σᵳ = fission cross section, σc = capture cross section

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.2, page 3-2. U-235 Fission Capture = σᵳ /(σᵳ + σc) = 577/(577+106) = 0.84
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.2, page 3-2. U-235 Fission Capture = σᵳ /(σᵳ + σc) = 577/(577+106) = 0.84
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.2, page 3-2. U-235 Fission Capture = σᵳ /(σᵳ + σc) = 577/(577+106) = 0.84
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 3.2, page 3-2. U-235 Fission Capture = σᵳ /(σᵳ + σc) = 577/(577+106) = 0.84

question: A.13 [1.0 point] The reactor is on a constant period. Which ONE of the following changes in reactor power would take the SHORTEST time?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 et/τ Ln(P/P0) = t/τ Since you are looking for which would take the SHORTEST time, the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 et/τ Ln(P/P0) = t/τ Since you are looking for which would take the SHORTEST time, the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.
Incorrect. REFERENCE: P = P0 et/τ Ln(P/P0) = t/τ Since you are looking for which would take the SHORTEST time, the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.
Correct. REFERENCE: P = P0 et/τ Ln(P/P0) = t/τ Since you are looking for which would take the SHORTEST time, the ratio P/P0 must be the smallest value.

question: A.15 [1.0 point] When large negative reactivity is inserted in the core, reactor power decreases by radioactive decay of the longest-lived source of delayed neutrons, Br-87, with a 55 second half-life. What is the shutdown period (T)?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 1.3.3, page 1-6. P(t) = P(o) eᵗ/τ = P(o) X exp(-0.693t/T2); t/T = -0.693t/T2; T = -T2/0.693 = -55/0.693 = -79.37 sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 1.3.3, page 1-6. P(t) = P(o) eᵗ/τ = P(o) X exp(-0.693t/T2); t/T = -0.693t/T2; T = -T2/0.693 = -55/0.693 = -79.37 sec
Correct. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 1.3.3, page 1-6. P(t) = P(o) eᵗ/τ = P(o) X exp(-0.693t/T2); t/T = -0.693t/T2; T = -T2/0.693 = -55/0.693 = -79.37 sec
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Burn, Introduction to Nuclear Reactor Operations, Section 1.3.3, page 1-6. P(t) = P(o) eᵗ/τ = P(o) X exp(-0.693t/T2); t/T = -0.693t/T2; T = -T2/0.693 = -55/0.693 = -79.37 sec

question: A.16 [1.0 point] A reactor contains a neutron source of 1200 neutrons/second. If the stable total neutron production rate is 4800 neutrons/second, what is the value of keff?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff); (1200) / (1 - keff) = 4800; keff = 0.75 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Correct. REFERENCE: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff); (1200) / (1 - keff) = 4800; keff = 0.75 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff); (1200) / (1 - keff) = 4800; keff = 0.75 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4
Incorrect. REFERENCE: Source CR = (S) / (1 – keff); (1200) / (1 - keff) = 4800; keff = 0.75 DOE Fundamentals Handbook Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Module 4, page 4

question: A.17 [1.0 point] Define β:

answers.answer: d. The fraction of neutrons at fast energies which were born as delayed neutrons.
answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Fundamentals Handbook, Nuclear Physics and Reactor Theory, Volume 1, Module 1, page 30

question: A.19 [1.0 point] If 0.141% Δk/k of positive reactivity is suddenly inserted into a critical reactor core, what will be the steady state reactor period? (Assume: B = 0.0072)
A.20 [1.0 point] The moderator temperature coefficient for a reactor is -0.00071 ∆k/k/oF. What is the total reactivity change caused by a temperature decrease of 75oF?

answers.feedback: Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Incorrect. REFERENCE: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k

Correct. REFERENCE: DOE Handbook Nuclear Physics & Reactor Theory, Volume 2, Section “Reactivity”, Subsection “Reactivity Coefficients and Reactivity Defect”, page 21, ∆ρ = αT*∆T = (-0.00071 ∆k/k /oF) * (-75oF) = 0.05325∆k/k
